To protect the body from external factors, regulate body temperature, and facilitate sensory perception, C. To produce sweat and sebum, D. To detect and respond to immune threats Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the name of the protein that fills skin cells as they move upwards to the surface? Options: A. Keratin, B. Collagen, C. Merkel, D. Langerhans Correct Option: A
Question 3: What percentage of the body's blood is circulating through the dermis at any given time? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 25%, D. 30% Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to the transcript, how often are skin cells replaced in the epidermis? Options: A. Every 2 weeks, B. Every 4 weeks, C. Every 6 weeks, D. Every 8 weeks Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the primary role of Langerhans cells in the skin? Options: A. To detect and respond to immune threats, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To produce sweat and secrete an oily substance that nourishes skin microbes, D. To facilitate sensory perception Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the phenomenon known as when hair stands upright across the body? Options: A. Goosebumps, B. Goosefeathers, C. Gooseflesh, D. Goosehairs Correct Option: A
Question 7: According to the transcript, what percentage of the body's weight is made up of skin? Options: A. 10%, B. 15%, C. 16%, D. 20% Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the main function of Merkel cells in the skin? Options: A. To detect and respond to immune threats, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To facilitate sensory perception, specifically the sense of touch, D. To produce sweat and sebum Correct Option: C

Question 10: What is the role of the sebaceous glands in the skin? Options: A. To produce sweat and regulate body temperature, B. To detect and respond to immune threats, C. To facilitate sensory perception, D. To secrete an oily substance that nourishes skin microbes Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Between you and the rest of the world 
lies an interface that makes up 16% of your physical weight. This is your skin, the largest organ 
in your body: laid out flat, it would cover close to 
1.7 square meters of ground. Its purpose may seem obvious—
to keep our insides in. But a look beyond the surface reveals that it plays a surprising 
number of roles in our lives. First, the basics. Skin is the foundation 
of the integumentary system, which also incorporates your hair, 
nails, and specialized glands and nerves. Made up of three layers, the epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis, skin’s thickness varies 
from 0.5 millimeters at its thinnest and up to four millimeters 
at its thickest. It also carries out three key functions: protecting, regulating, and sensing the world beyond its limits. On a daily basis, its huge surface 
processes hundreds, if not thousands, of physical sensations, relying mostly on large, 
pressure-sensitive skin components called Merkel cells. In your fingertips alone, there are 750 Merkel cells 
per each square-centimeter of skin, coupled with over 2,500 receptors
that give you your sense of touch. This surface is also the body’s first 
major line of defense. Without it, you’d be a soggy mass 
of tissue and fluids, fatally exposed to the elements. Skin effectively seals off your insides and also absorbs pressure and shock with flexible collagen 
that makes up most of its dermal layer. The epidermis is made up mainly 
of skin cells called keratinocytes that are completely replaced 
every four weeks. As new cells form at the base of the
epidermis, older ones are pushed up. When these cells move upwards, they’re filled with a hardened protein 
called keratin. Once they reach the surface, they form a tightly-overlapping, 
waterproof layer that’s difficult for invading 
microbes to breach. Any harmful microbes that make it 
into the epidermis will encounter Langerhans cells. This group of protective skin cells 
detects invaders and communicates their presence 
to resident immune system T-cells, which react by launching 
an immune response. A crucial feature of this immune defense is the several thousand 
species of microorganisms that inhabit the planes, folds, and crevices of your skin. These microbes, 
which include bacteria and fungi, thrive in the sebum, an oily substance that’s secreted 
onto the skin’s surface by sebaceous glands nestled
inside the dermis. These skin microbes keep the immune system
in a state of constant surveillance, ensuring that it’s ready to react 
if the body really is at risk. Beyond this protective role, your skin is also a sensory organ that
helps regulate your body’s temperature, two roles that are closely interlinked. Nerves detect whether your skin 
is warm or cold and communicate that
information to your brain. In return, the brain instructs
localized blood vessels to either expand if the body is too warm, releasing heat from 
the blood through the skin, or to constrict if the body is cold,
which retains heat. At any given time, up to 25% of the body's
blood is circulating through the dermis, making this process extremely efficient. Under warm conditions, the skin’s sweat glands will secrete sweat
via ducts onto the surface, transferring heat out of the body. Hair can also be stimulated
to conserve or release body warmth. The average human 
has 5 million hair follicles embedded everywhere on the body except the palms of your hands 
and soles of your feet. Ninety to 150,000 of those 
are on your scalp, where they help shield
the large surface area of your head from physical damage and sunburn. When you're cold, tiny muscles 
called arrector pilli cause hair to stand upright
across the body. That’s the phenomenon known as goosebumps
and it traps body heat close to your skin. Skin’s vast surface isn’t just a shield; it also enables us to interact 
and connect with the world. Its multifunctional layer cools us down
and keeps us warm. The integumentary system 
may be many things, but it’s certainly more than skin deep.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: We rely on ______ to give us our sense of touch.
Options: A. The skin’s enormous surface area, B. The sensitive hairs on the surface of our skin, C. Collagen fibers, D. Merkel cells and nerve cells
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is King Midas known as in Greek mythology? Options: A. A god of wine and carnival, B. A wise and just ruler, C. A rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people and distracted the gods, D. A satyr Correct Option: C
Question 2: What gift did Dionysus offer to grant King Midas? Options: A. A magical amulet, B. A year's supply of wine, C. A new palace, D. The power to turn anything he touched to gold Correct Option: D
Question 3: What happened to King Midas's daughter when he touched her with his golden hands? Options: A. She was turned into a golden statue, B. She was given a magical amulet, C. She was granted the power to turn anything to gold, D. She was turned into a satyr Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did King Midas regain his normal hands? Options: A. By performing a ritual dance, B. By making a wish to Dionysus, C. By being transformed into a donkey, D. By washing his hands in the River Pactolus Correct Option: D
Question 5: What did King Midas say about Pan, the music and sun god, that led to his punishment? Options: A. That he was a great musician, B. That he was a poor musician, C. That he was a greater musician than Apollo, D. That he was a musician at all Correct Option: C
Question 6: What happened to King Midas's ears as a result of Apollo's punishment? Options: A. They were turned into gold, B. They were transformed into a satyr's ears, C. They were turned into the ears of an ass, D. They were cut off Correct Option: C
Question 7: What did King Midas's barber do to keep his secret about the king's ears? Options: A. He told everyone in the kingdom, B. He kept it to himself and fought the desire to tell someone, C. He wrote it down in a book, D. He drew a picture of it Correct Option: B
Question 8: What happened to the barber when he whispered the secret to the ground? Options: A. A magical amulet appeared, B. A statue of the king was erected, C. A clump of reeds sprang up and carried the echo of his whisper through the breeze, D. The ground began to shake Correct Option: C
Question 9: What did the people of the kingdom remember King Midas for? Options: A. His wise and just rule, B. His golden touch and ass's ears, C. His magical amulet, D. His satyr-like features Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the rustle of the Phrygian wind in the story? Options: A. It symbolizes the king's wisdom and justice, B. It represents the people's laughter and ridicule of the king, C. It signifies the kingdom's prosperity and peace, D. It is a metaphor for the king's magical powers Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Between you and the rest of the world 
lies an interface that makes up 16% of your physical weight. This is your skin, the largest organ 
in your body: laid out flat, it would cover close to 
1.7 square meters of ground. Its purpose may seem obvious—
to keep our insides in. But a look beyond the surface reveals that it plays a surprising 
number of roles in our lives. First, the basics. Skin is the foundation 
of the integumentary system, which also incorporates your hair, 
nails, and specialized glands and nerves. Made up of three layers, the epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis, skin’s thickness varies 
from 0.5 millimeters at its thinnest and up to four millimeters 
at its thickest. It also carries out three key functions: protecting, regulating, and sensing the world beyond its limits. On a daily basis, its huge surface 
processes hundreds, if not thousands, of physical sensations, relying mostly on large, 
pressure-sensitive skin components called Merkel cells. In your fingertips alone, there are 750 Merkel cells 
per each square-centimeter of skin, coupled with over 2,500 receptors
that give you your sense of touch. This surface is also the body’s first 
major line of defense. Without it, you’d be a soggy mass 
of tissue and fluids, fatally exposed to the elements. Skin effectively seals off your insides and also absorbs pressure and shock with flexible collagen 
that makes up most of its dermal layer. The epidermis is made up mainly 
of skin cells called keratinocytes that are completely replaced 
every four weeks. As new cells form at the base of the
epidermis, older ones are pushed up. When these cells move upwards, they’re filled with a hardened protein 
called keratin. Once they reach the surface, they form a tightly-overlapping, 
waterproof layer that’s difficult for invading 
microbes to breach. Any harmful microbes that make it 
into the epidermis will encounter Langerhans cells. This group of protective skin cells 
detects invaders and communicates their presence 
to resident immune system T-cells, which react by launching 
an immune response. A crucial feature of this immune defense is the several thousand 
species of microorganisms that inhabit the planes, folds, and crevices of your skin. These microbes, 
which include bacteria and fungi, thrive in the sebum, an oily substance that’s secreted 
onto the skin’s surface by sebaceous glands nestled
inside the dermis. These skin microbes keep the immune system
in a state of constant surveillance, ensuring that it’s ready to react 
if the body really is at risk. Beyond this protective role, your skin is also a sensory organ that
helps regulate your body’s temperature, two roles that are closely interlinked. Nerves detect whether your skin 
is warm or cold and communicate that
information to your brain. In return, the brain instructs
localized blood vessels to either expand if the body is too warm, releasing heat from 
the blood through the skin, or to constrict if the body is cold,
which retains heat. At any given time, up to 25% of the body's
blood is circulating through the dermis, making this process extremely efficient. Under warm conditions, the skin’s sweat glands will secrete sweat
via ducts onto the surface, transferring heat out of the body. Hair can also be stimulated
to conserve or release body warmth. The average human 
has 5 million hair follicles embedded everywhere on the body except the palms of your hands 
and soles of your feet. Ninety to 150,000 of those 
are on your scalp, where they help shield
the large surface area of your head from physical damage and sunburn. When you're cold, tiny muscles 
called arrector pilli cause hair to stand upright
across the body. That’s the phenomenon known as goosebumps
and it traps body heat close to your skin. Skin’s vast surface isn’t just a shield; it also enables us to interact 
and connect with the world. Its multifunctional layer cools us down
and keeps us warm. The integumentary system 
may be many things, but it’s certainly more than skin deep.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: We rely on ______ to give us our sense of touch.
Options: A. The skin’s enormous surface area, B. The sensitive hairs on the surface of our skin, C. Collagen fibers, D. Merkel cells and nerve cells
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: What gift did Dionysus offer to grant King Midas? Options: A. A magical amulet, B. A year's supply of wine, C. A new palace, D. The power to turn anything he touched to gold Correct Option: D
Question 3: What happened to King Midas's daughter when he touched her with his golden hands? Options: A. She was turned into a golden statue, B. She was given a magical amulet, C. She was granted the power to turn anything to gold, D. She was turned into a satyr Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did King Midas regain his normal hands? Options: A. By performing a ritual dance, B. By making a wish to Dionysus, C. By being transformed into a donkey, D. By washing his hands in the River Pactolus Correct Option: D
Question 5: What did King Midas say about Pan, the music and sun god, that led to his punishment? Options: A. That he was a great musician, B. That he was a poor musician, C. That he was a greater musician than Apollo, D. That he was a musician at all Correct Option: C
Question 6: What happened to King Midas's ears as a result of Apollo's punishment? Options: A. They were turned into gold, B. They were transformed into a satyr's ears, C. They were turned into the ears of an ass, D. They were cut off Correct Option: C
Question 7: What did King Midas's barber do to keep his secret about the king's ears? Options: A. He told everyone in the kingdom, B. He kept it to himself and fought the desire to tell someone, C. He wrote it down in a book, D. He drew a picture of it Correct Option: B
Question 8: What happened to the barber when he whispered the secret to the ground? Options: A. A magical amulet appeared, B. A statue of the king was erected, C. A clump of reeds sprang up and carried the echo of his whisper through the breeze, D. The ground began to shake Correct Option: C
Question 9: What did the people of the kingdom remember King Midas for? Options: A. His wise and just rule, B. His golden touch and ass's ears, C. His magical amulet, D. His satyr-like features Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the rustle of the Phrygian wind in the story? Options: A. It symbolizes the king's wisdom and justice, B. It represents the people's laughter and ridicule of the king, C. It signifies the kingdom's prosperity and peace, D. It is a metaphor for the king's magical powers Correct Option: B

Between you and the rest of the world 
lies an interface that makes up 16% of your physical weight. This is your skin, the largest organ 
in your body: laid out flat, it would cover close to 
1.7 square meters of ground. Its purpose may seem obvious—

may be many things, but it’s certainly more than skin deep.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Midas was the king of ______.
Options: A. Greece, B. Troy, C. Phrygia, D. Phoenicia
Correct Option: C

Question 17: What was the nature of the drinking horn that Thor was given? Options: A. It was a normal drinking horn, B. It was filled with a normal liquid, C. It was filled with the ocean, D. It was filled with mead Correct Option: C
Question 18: What was the result of Thor's attempt to lift the cat? Options: A. He was able to lift it easily, B. He was able to lift it with some effort, C. He was only able to lift one paw, D. He was not able to lift it at all Correct Option: C
Question 19: What was the nature of the challenges presented to Thor and his companions? Options: A. They were physical challenges, B. They were mental challenges, C. They were tests of their abilities, D. They were illusions Correct Option: D
Question 20: What did the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, reveal to Thor and his companions at the end of the story? Options: A. That they had passed all the challenges, B. That they had failed all the challenges, C. That the challenges were illusions, D. That they had changed the world Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Dionysus was the Greek god of ______.
Options: A. Gold, B. Carnival, C. Kings, D. Horses
Correct Option: B

That he had pushed himself harder than ever before and changed the world, D. That he was the best at everything Correct Option: C

Question 9: What was the significance of the challenges presented to Thor and his companions? Options: A. They were a test of their physical strength, B. They were a test of their mental strength, C. They were a test of their ability to adapt to new situations, D. They were a test of their ability to work together as a team Correct Option: C

By pushing themselves harder than ever before and changing the world in ways no one had expected, D. By running away Correct Option: C

Question 13: What was the nature of Elli, the giant that Thor wrestled? Options: A. Elli was a human, B. Elli was a giant, C. Elli was old age, D. Elli was a monster Correct Option: C

Question 15: What was the significance of the challenges presented to Loki? Options: A. They were a test of his physical strength, B. They were a test of his mental strength, C. They were a test of his ability to adapt to new situations, D. They were a test of his ability to eat quickly Correct Option: D
Question 16: What was the result of the eating contest between Loki and Logi? Options: A. Loki ate more than Logi, B. Logi ate more than Loki, C. They ate the same amount, D. Loki and Logi did not participate in the contest Correct Option: B
Question 17: What was the nature of the drinking horn that Thor was given? Options: A. It was a normal drinking horn, B. It was filled with a normal liquid, C. It was filled with the ocean, D. It was filled with mead Correct Option: C
Question 18: What was the result of Thor's attempt to lift the cat? Options: A. He was able to lift it easily, B. He was able to lift it with some effort, C. He was only able to lift one paw, D. He was not able to lift it at all Correct Option: C
Question 19: What was the nature of the challenges presented to Thor and his companions? Options: A. They were physical challenges, B. They were mental challenges, C. They were tests of their abilities, D. They were illusions Correct Option: D

That they had failed all the challenges, C. That the challenges were illusions, D. That they had changed the world Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Midas washed his hands in the River Pactolus ______.
Options: A. To increase his power, B. To bring his daughter back to life, C. As part of a ritual for Dionysus, D. To rid himself of the golden touch
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

Options: A. He doubted his talent, B. He disrespected him, C. He sacrificed a donkey, D. He doubted his talent and disrespected him, E. He doubted his talent and sacrificed a donkey
Correct Option: D

The generated MCQs appear to be related to a different story, likely from Norse mythology, whereas the ground truth MCQ is related to the story of King Midas from Greek mythology.

This question does not match the content or options of the ground truth MCQ, but it does involve a character (Loki) who is known for causing trouble and disrespecting other gods, similar to how King Midas disrespected Apollo.

That being said, I must emphasize that none of the generated MCQs are a good match for the ground truth MCQ, and a new set of generated MCQs that are specifically related to the story of King Midas would be needed to find a suitable match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When he learned the king’s secret, the barber ______.
Options: A. Didn’t tell another human, B. Told only his wife, C. Whispered it to the other barbers, D. Told everyone immediately
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the giant that Thor met on his journey to Jotunheim, who offered to accompany them and carry their provisions in his bag? Options: A. Skrymir, B. Utgard-Loki, C. Logi, D. Hugi Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the name of the trickster god who accompanied Thor and Thjalfi on their journey? Options: A. Loki, B. Thor, C. Odin, D. Skrymir Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the reason behind Thor's failure in the drinking horn challenge? Options: A. He was too slow, B. The drinking horn was filled with the ocean, C. He was too weak, D. He didn't drink enough Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did Loki lose the eating contest against Logi? Options: A. Because he ate too slowly, B. Because Logi was the embodiment of thought, C. Because Logi was wildfire itself, D. Because Loki was too weak Correct Option: C
Question 5: What might Thor use his strength to help others in real-world scenarios? Options: A. He could use his hammer to crush obstacles, B. He could use his hammer to defend people from harm, C. He could use his strength to lift heavy objects, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was the relationship between Skrymir and Utgard-Loki, according to the story? Options: A. They were brothers, B. Skrymir was Utgard-Loki in disguise, C. Skrymir was Utgard-Loki's servant, D. They were friends Correct Option: B
Question 7: What did Thor learn from his failure in the challenges presented to him? Options: A. That he was stronger than the giants, B. That he was weaker than the giants, C. That he had pushed himself harder than ever before and changed the world, D. That he was the best at everything Correct Option: C
Question 8: How did the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, test Thor's strength in the challenge of lifting his pet cat? Options: A. By making the cat heavier, B. By making the cat lighter, C. By making the cat as tall as Thor, D. By making the cat invisible Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the significance of the challenges presented to Thor and his companions? Options: A. They were a test of their physical strength, B. They were a test of their mental strength, C. They were a test of their ability to adapt to new situations, D. They were a test of their ability to work together as a team Correct Option: C
Question 10: How did Thor and his companions change the world, despite failing the challenges presented to them? Options: A. By defeating the giants, B. By lifting the cat, C. By pushing themselves harder than ever before and changing the world in ways no one had expected, D. By running away Correct Option: C
Question 11: Who was the giant that Thor wrestled in the challenge, and what was the outcome? Options: A. Hugi, Thor won, B. Elli, Thor won, C. Elli, Thor lost, D. Hugi, Thor lost Correct Option: C
Question 12: What was the nature of Hugi, the giant that Thjalfi ran against? Options: A. Hugi was a human, B. Hugi was a giant, C. Hugi was the embodiment of thought, D. Hugi was a monster Correct Option: C
Question 13: What was the nature of Elli, the giant that Thor wrestled? Options: A. Elli was a human, B. Elli was a giant, C. Elli was old age, D. Elli was a monster Correct Option: C
Question 14: What was the outcome of the challenges presented to Thjalfi? Options: A. He won all the challenges, B. He lost all the challenges, C. He won some challenges but lost others, D. He didn't participate in the challenges Correct Option: B
Question 15: What was the significance of the challenges presented to Loki? Options: A. They were a test of his physical strength, B. They were a test of his mental strength, C. They were a test of his ability to adapt to new situations, D. They were a test of his ability to eat quickly Correct Option: D
Question 16: What was the result of the eating contest between Loki and Logi? Options: A. Loki ate more than Logi, B. Logi ate more than Loki, C. They ate the same amount, D. Loki and Logi did not participate in the contest Correct Option: B
Question 17: What was the nature of the drinking horn that Thor was given? Options: A. It was a normal drinking horn, B. It was filled with a normal liquid, C. It was filled with the ocean, D. It was filled with mead Correct Option: C
Question 18: What was the result of Thor's attempt to lift the cat? Options: A. He was able to lift it easily, B. He was able to lift it with some effort, C. He was only able to lift one paw, D. He was not able to lift it at all Correct Option: C
Question 19: What was the nature of the challenges presented to Thor and his companions? Options: A. They were physical challenges, B. They were mental challenges, C. They were tests of their abilities, D. They were illusions Correct Option: D
Question 20: What did the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, reveal to Thor and his companions at the end of the story? Options: A. That they had passed all the challenges, B. That they had failed all the challenges, C. That the challenges were illusions, D. That they had changed the world Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor is known as _______.
Options: A. The protector of mankind, B. The trickster god, C. The god of thunder, D. The protector of mankind and the god of thunder, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate population of the Inca Empire? Options: A. 5 million subjects, B. 7 million subjects, C. 10 million subjects, D. 15 million subjects Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to legend, where did the ancestors of the Inca rulers emerge from? Options: A. A cave called Tambo Toco, B. The Cuzco Valley, C. The Andes mountains, D. The Amazon rainforest Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the name of the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas? Options: A. Ayar Manco, B. Manco Capac, C. Pachacuti, D. Viracocha Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the name of the system of knotted strings used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. Inca Quipu System Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the name of the famous estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign? Options: A. Machu Picchu, B. Cuzco Palace, C. Inca Temple, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 6: What were the main reasons for the decline of the Inca Empire? Options: A. Civil war and disease, B. Spanish conquest and disease, C. Both civil war and Spanish conquest, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 7: Who was the leader of the Spanish conquistadors who defeated the Inca Empire? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the name of the decimal-based system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 9: When did the Spanish conquistadors arrive in the Caribbean? Options: A. 1491 CE, B. 1492 CE, C. 1500 CE, D. 1510 CE Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the name of the new capital established by the Incas after the fall of Cuzco? Options: A. Vilcabamba, B. Machu Picchu, C. Cuzco Palace, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 11: Who was the Inca king who expanded Inca rule throughout the Andes mountains and transformed the kingdom into an empire? Options: A. Viracocha, B. Pachacuti, C. Topa Inca, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: B
Question 12: What was the name of the empire's territory reorganized by Pachacuti, which consisted of four divisions ruled by governors reporting to the king? Options: A. Tahuantinsuyu, B. Cuzco Empire, C. Inca Kingdom, D. Andean Empire Correct Option: A
Question 13: What was the main reason for the weakening of the Inca Empire in 1524? Options: A. The death of Huayna Capac, B. Civil war, C. Disease, D. Spanish conquest Correct Option: A
Question 14: Who was the leader of the Incas who encountered the European invaders in 1532? Options: A. Atahualpa, B. Huascar, C. Pachacuti, D. Viracocha Correct Option: A
Question 15: What was the name of the decimal-based system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 16: When did the Spanish conquistadors destroy all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas' physical and cultural legacy? Options: A. 1524 CE, B. 1532 CE, C. 1572 CE, D. 1600 CE Correct Option: C
Question 17: Who was the Inca king who succeeded Topa Inca in 1493? Options: A. Atahualpa, B. Huascar, C. Pachacuti, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: D
Question 18: What was the name of the estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign, which is located in the Andes mountains? Options: A. Machu Picchu, C. Inca Temple, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 19: Who was the leader of the Spanish conquistadors who described the capital of Cuzco as "so beautiful that it would be remarkable even in Spain"? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: A
Question 20: When did the Inca Empire fall even faster than it had risen? Options: A. 1524 CE, B. 1532 CE, C. 1572 CE, D. 1600 CE Correct Option: C

and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest

Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim,

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor tries to wake the sleeping giant named Skrymir by _______.
Options: A. Dropping acorns on his head, B. Tickling him with a leaf under his chin, C. Noisily searching his bag of goods, D. Striking the giant’s head with his hammer
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate population of the Inca Empire? Options: A. 5 million subjects, B. 7 million subjects, C. 10 million subjects, D. 15 million subjects Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to legend, where did the ancestors of the Inca rulers emerge from? Options: A. A cave called Tambo Toco, B. The Cuzco Valley, C. The Andes mountains, D. The Amazon rainforest Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the name of the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas? Options: A. Ayar Manco, B. Manco Capac, C. Pachacuti, D. Viracocha Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the name of the system of knotted strings used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. Inca Quipu System Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the name of the famous estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign? Options: A. Machu Picchu, B. Cuzco Palace, C. Inca Temple, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 6: What were the main reasons for the decline of the Inca Empire? Options: A. Civil war and disease, B. Spanish conquest and disease, C. Both civil war and Spanish conquest, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 7: Who was the leader of the Spanish conquistadors who defeated the Inca Empire? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the name of the decimal-based system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 9: When did the Spanish conquistadors arrive in the Caribbean? Options: A. 1491 CE, B. 1492 CE, C. 1500 CE, D. 1510 CE Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the name of the new capital established by the Incas after the fall of Cuzco? Options: A. Vilcabamba, B. Machu Picchu, C. Cuzco Palace, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 11: Who was the Inca king who expanded Inca rule throughout the Andes mountains and transformed the kingdom into an empire? Options: A. Viracocha, B. Pachacuti, C. Topa Inca, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: B
Question 12: What was the name of the empire's territory reorganized by Pachacuti, which consisted of four divisions ruled by governors reporting to the king? Options: A. Tahuantinsuyu, B. Cuzco Empire, C. Inca Kingdom, D. Andean Empire Correct Option: A
Question 13: What was the main reason for the weakening of the Inca Empire in 1524? Options: A. The death of Huayna Capac, B. Civil war, C. Disease, D. Spanish conquest Correct Option: A
Question 14: Who was the leader of the Incas who encountered the European invaders in 1532? Options: A. Atahualpa, B. Huascar, C. Pachacuti, D. Viracocha Correct Option: A
Question 15: What was the name of the decimal-based system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 16: When did the Spanish conquistadors destroy all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas' physical and cultural legacy? Options: A. 1524 CE, B. 1532 CE, C. 1572 CE, D. 1600 CE Correct Option: C
Question 17: Who was the Inca king who succeeded Topa Inca in 1493? Options: A. Atahualpa, B. Huascar, C. Pachacuti, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: D
Question 18: What was the name of the estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign, which is located in the Andes mountains? Options: A. Machu Picchu, C. Inca Temple, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 19: Who was the leader of the Spanish conquistadors who described the capital of Cuzco as "so beautiful that it would be remarkable even in Spain"? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: A
Question 20: When did the Inca Empire fall even faster than it had risen? Options: A. 1524 CE, B. 1532 CE, C. 1572 CE, D. 1600 CE Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli,

never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The drinking horn was filled with the ocean. Thor drank enough of it to cause _______.
Options: A. A tsunami, B. The tides, C. A drought, D. Boats to capsize
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate population of the Inca Empire? Options: A. 5 million subjects, B. 7 million subjects, C. 10 million subjects, D. 15 million subjects Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to legend, where did the ancestors of the Inca rulers emerge from? Options: A. A cave called Tambo Toco, B. The Cuzco Valley, C. The Andes mountains, D. The Amazon rainforest Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the name of the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas? Options: A. Ayar Manco, B. Manco Capac, C. Pachacuti, D. Viracocha Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the name of the system of knotted strings used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. Inca Quipu System Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the name of the famous estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign? Options: A. Machu Picchu, B. Cuzco Palace, C. Inca Temple, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 6: What were the main reasons for the decline of the Inca Empire? Options: A. Civil war and disease, B. Spanish conquest and disease, C. Both civil war and Spanish conquest, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 7: Who was the leader of the Spanish conquistadors who defeated the Inca Empire? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the name of the decimal-based system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 9: When did the Spanish conquistadors arrive in the Caribbean? Options: A. 1491 CE, B. 1492 CE, C. 1500 CE, D. 1510 CE Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the name of the new capital established by the Incas after the fall of Cuzco? Options: A. Vilcabamba, B. Machu Picchu, C. Cuzco Palace, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 11: Who was the Inca king who expanded Inca rule throughout the Andes mountains and transformed the kingdom into an empire? Options: A. Viracocha, B. Pachacuti, C. Topa Inca, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: B
Question 12: What was the name of the empire's territory reorganized by Pachacuti, which consisted of four divisions ruled by governors reporting to the king? Options: A. Tahuantinsuyu, B. Cuzco Empire, C. Inca Kingdom, D. Andean Empire Correct Option: A
Question 13: What was the main reason for the weakening of the Inca Empire in 1524? Options: A. The death of Huayna Capac, B. Civil war, C. Disease, D. Spanish conquest Correct Option: A
Question 14: Who was the leader of the Incas who encountered the European invaders in 1532? Options: A. Atahualpa, B. Huascar, C. Pachacuti, D. Viracocha Correct Option: A
Question 15: What was the name of the decimal-based system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Cuzco Code, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 16: When did the Spanish conquistadors destroy all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas' physical and cultural legacy? Options: A. 1524 CE, B. 1532 CE, C. 1572 CE, D. 1600 CE Correct Option: C
Question 17: Who was the Inca king who succeeded Topa Inca in 1493? Options: A. Atahualpa, B. Huascar, C. Pachacuti, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: D
Question 18: What was the name of the estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign, which is located in the Andes mountains? Options: A. Machu Picchu, C. Inca Temple, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A

Question 20: When did the Inca Empire fall even faster than it had risen? Options: A. 1524 CE, B. 1532 CE, C. 1572 CE, D. 1600 CE Correct Option: C
